column1: # # Named Entity Recognition with Conditional Random Fields
# One of the classic challenges of Natural Language Processing is sequence labelling. In sequence labelling
column2: the goal is to label each word in a text with a word class. In part-of-speech tagging
column3: these word classes are parts of speech
column4: such as noun or verb. In named entity recognition (NER)
column5: they're types of generic named entities
column9: such as diseases or symptoms in the healthcare domain. In this way
column10: sequence labelling can help us extract the most important information from a text and improve the performance of analytics

column1: # In this notebook we'll explore Conditional Random Fields
column2: the most popular approach to sequence labelling before Deep Learning arrived. Deep Learning may get all the attention right now
column3: but Conditional Random Fields are still a powerful tool to build a simple sequence labeller.

column1: # The tool we're going to use is `sklearn-crfsuite`. This is a wrapper around `python-crfsuite`
column2: which itself is a Python binding of [CRFSuite](http://www.chokkan.org/software/crfsuite/). The reason we're using `sklearn-crfsuite` is that it provides a number of handy utility functions
column3: for example for evaluating the output of the model. You can install it with `pip install sklearn-crfsuite`.

column1: # First we get some data. A well-known data set for training and testing NER models is the CoNLL-2002 data
column2: which has Spanish and Dutch texts labelled with four types of entities: locations (LOC)
column3: persons (PER)
column4: organizations (ORG) and miscellaneous entities (MISC). Both corpora are split up in three portions: a training portion and two smaller test portions
column5: one of which we'll use as development data. It's easy to collect the data from NLTK.

column1: # The data consists of a list of tokenized sentences. For each of the tokens we have the string itself
column2: its part-of-speech tag and its entity tag
column3: which follows the BIO convention. In the deep learning world we live in today
column4: it's common to ignore the part-of-speech tags. However
column5: since CRFs rely on good feature extraction
column6: we'll gladly make use of this information. After all
column7: the part of speech of a word tells us a lot about its possible status as a named entity: nouns will more often be entities than verbs

column1: # Whereas today neural networks are expected to learn the relevant features of the input texts themselves
column2: this is very different with Conditional Random Fields. CRFs learn the relationship between the features we give them and the label of a token in a given context. They're not going to earn these features themselves. Instead
column3: the quality of the model will depend highly on the relevance of the features we show it.

column1: # The most important method in this tutorial is therefore the one that collects the features for every token. What information could be useful? The word itself
column3: together with its part of speech tag. It can also be interesting to know whether the word is completely uppercase
column4: whether it starts with a capital or is a digit. In addition
column5: we also take a look at the character bigram and trigram the word ends with. We also give every token a `bias` feature
column6: which always has the same value. This bias feature helps the CRF learn the relative frequency of each label type in the training data.

column1: # So far we've trained a model with the default parameters. It's unlikely that these will give us the best performance possible. Therefore we're going to search automatically for the best hyperparameter settings by iteratively training different models and evaluating them. Eventually we'll pick the best one.
# Here we'll focus on two parameters: `c1` and `c2`. These are the parameters for L1 and L2 regularization
column2: respectively. Regularization prevents overfitting on the training data by adding a penalty to the loss function. In L1 regularization
column3: this penalty is the sum of the absolute values of the weights; in L2 regularization
column4: it is the sum of the squared weights. L1 regularization performs a type of feature selection
column5: as it assigns 0 weight to irrelevant features. L2 regularization
column7: makes the weight of irrelevant features small
column8: but not necessarily zero. L1 regularization is often called the Lasso method
column9: L2 is called the Ridge method
column10: and the linear combination of both is called Elastic Net regularization.
